Name: Deon
Comment: This is only my second clip of Noah so I might need to see more to have a better conclusion. But so far I feel you have the best intentions of wanting to shed light on the problems the manosphere seems to have especially the relationship misconceptions with women. I applaud you for the effort. I've watched red pill content but always with a grain of salt as I could never agree with everything they say or their approach to relationships. They do however bring up some of the double standards and unfair expectations society has for men to which I can confirm from my own experience. That being said looking through the comments it seems despite your best efforts to bring a healthy light on some of their problematic issues the praise of your positive intent is a bit overshadowed by the glee of bashing the subjects of your analysis. Not your fault at all but the comments very much resemble the comments on some of the redpill content creators i've watched. Youtube is full of echo chambers so this isn't surprising but folks that watch seem to have their hate of the content creators validated and then basically high five each other and go "yeah they suck" collectively. Its all just the same stuff. A group state their beliefs and ridicules those that don't share their beliefs then another groups responds and ridicules them back and vice versa. I still will watch more of your content cause you're funny and have good critique. Just don't know if your audience will lean more pro positivity or more collective bashing; not that yt has any shortage.

@Four Lights Orchestra Absolutely, the world has changed but the weird outmoded beliefs and stereotypes persist under the belief they're "natural" or "correct."

And don't worry about the wording at all, I wasn't being super critical. Apologies if I seemed that way.

Name: Four Lights Orchestra
Comment: @Bearded Bear Yeah, I worded that horribly, I meant from a time where women made drastically (even more than now) less than men. I realize the pay gap is still a thing, but I mean it's a different world now where it's not an uncommon thing for a woman to work a full time job, as I'm not sure how common that was prior to the 1930's. That's a theme I see come up in pre code Hollywood movies, that a woman being independent and working was a relatively new way to live.

Name: Bearded Bear
Comment:
Well, you're mostly right. Men however still make more. The gender pay gap was and still is a real thing. However, the further back you go the more difficult it was for a woman to be financially independent. As recently as 1950's America for instance, women were often refused their own bank account. 

Either they were expected to have one gifted to them by a parent, usually the father, or expected to use their husband's. This wasn't universally true of course, but it was common enough that it gave rise to a whole pile of stereotypes and "gender norms" that persist to this day.

Name: Jacky
Comment:
There's like...a massive issue in the biology community I think that unfortunately helps play into this way of thinking. Animal behaviorists often liken how animals choose mates to how humans go about dating, and they try way too hard to explain away all human dating behaviors as biologically inherent. While some of them certainly are (like dressing nicely for a date), there's a lot that aren't and are just a product of how the society we've built is structured. Those can't really be explained with biology but a lot of biologists do their hardest to try.  

So when biologists are out here saying, oh, women will go after men who are older and have more money because they need a male to provide for them, because biology, redpill guys will absolutely eat that up. It's a viewpoint that is really centered around how men feel in a patriarchal society and fails to capture any nuance in human dating or the reality of human lifestyles. Men aren't the only ones who put on a show for a potential partner's attention--women do that too. Men aren't the only providers to a family--women do that too.

It's just annoying, how even biologists subscribe to this idea that a patriarchy exists for a reason, and actively push for massively bioessentialist views on human behavior. People might argue against this and say, well, something being biologically based doesn't necessarily mean it's okay, and it's just a simple fact. And, yeah, but think about what you are arguing for there. That women are biologically just submissive and meek and peaceful, and men are dominant and loud and violent, and that's the truth? That helps nobody and is transphobic and misogynistic. But because it's "biology" people take it as fact and use as an excuse for shitty men's behavior, and it just gives incels/alpha male types more ammunition.

Name: Cerebral Support
Comment:
I actually do have a very reasonable answer to the "who pays for the date?" question: _Whoever invites the other person(s) on the date, is the one that pays_ 
So if you ask someone(s) out on a date, it's understood that you're paying for the date and vise versa. That way it stays pretty even throughout the relationship and eventually paying for the date will be seen as a romantic gesture. It'll also still allow you/your partner(s) to go on dates even if one of you is short on cash that month.

Name: Nyshyn
Comment: 11:30 I would disagree that the counter-content is specific for one major reason: there are no real alternative communities offered. That's important because a lot of men fall into Redpill communities since it's one they feel prioritized in. Of course a lot of bad advice is tossed around but the lonely audience these guys appeal to isn't going to be swayed by "just treat women well", "most women aren't like this", "this is a result of the patriarchy that you should be working to dismantle",  or "stop focusing so much on relationships" because many of them feel such thinkings already haven't gotten them anywhere. They essentially view videos like those as whataboutism because the people making them don't prioritize tangible steps and solutions to men's issues as opposed to telling them why the redpill is toxic. It's of course important to say why redpillers and their beliefs are toxic but until these kinds of videos prioritize alternative solutions and communities where men are prioritized, I think they'll remain unconvinced

Name: Sara Lee
Comment: The argument is women can sleep with who they wish to has overt flaws, some quantifiable and the others quantifiable. If I may sleep with whomever I wish, then that man is also sleeping with who he wishes to sleep with, unless the argument is that men are constantly assaulted by women who force them into sex. Sex requires two people. Everyone is relegated to intimacy based on access, availability and their willingness to participate. There are amazingly beautiful and kind women all over the world, however, they are still limited by their access to and the willingness of the objects of their  attractions to be mutually invested in pursuing them. What their arguments seem to be is that men have no agency. Another problem half of these videos drone on about is all of women who are "for the streets," which precludes their desire to be with those women. Therefore, those women do not have access to them, per their own admission, so both cannot be true... So, women can sleep with whomever they want, just not them, but the man who she is having sex must be an unwilling participant, as only the woman is with who she wants to be with... unless you are over weight, over 26 years old, had any previous relationships, a child, or childhood male friends. Also, submission is intrinsic to compromise, something everyone does in any relationship. Both parties will submit, depending on each other's stake in the outcome.  They do not want submission, they want ownership over someone else's existence. Lastly, men do express emotion all the time. These manosphere videos are all highly emotional. You see insecurity, sadness, pain, jealousy, hurt, anger and all sorts of feelings. Even if their affect is incongruent with these emotions, the words are. You do not need to physically cry to express pain or sadness. All I see when I watch this stuff is insecurity, hurt and pain, described by people ill-equipped to manage it. Even if they had a woman to do everything they said, it wouldn't be enough, because what they are missing cannot be filled with another person. No one can make you happy, rather you share your happiness with each other, or they do not supress your ability to be happy. Meaning, individually happy people are more successful at relationships, than people who expect to be made happy through their partner's behaviours. You may be happy with your relationship, but it should not be because of it. That is too much pressure and an unfair delegation of responsibility to the other party. It is why compatibility is paramount, because you will have more things which you both find happiness in together, without having to be uncomfortable for the sake of each other's happiness. If all of the women, or men, you encounter all end the same, you're the constant. Meaning, 20 different people, from different life experiences met you, but your dissatisfaction remains the same, then the probability favours you being the catalyst for the 20 negative outcomes, not the twenty other people... or you should gamble

Name: Abel Abel
Comment:
@wealth mindset Your example illustrates precisely what I was saying.

You looked at those numbers and felt that marriage is not in your best interest. This is how you *feel* about the data.

You, with your bias and the overarching narrative that sees relationships as transactions, look at the data and conclude that this happens because it is nature, or because women are interested in money, or any other similar thing. One could look at the same data and ask why those numbers are like that, like Eveliina did. Values of the patriarchy makes women care more for the children while men can focus more on careers, which is a good explanation for the numbers you see, as they mentioned. Therefore, feminism seeking to dismantle such values would be the answer for you, not the rEd PiLl. 

You could claim it is biological, of course. But then you'd have to explain why different societies have different numbers or, more importantly, radically different social structures. There are and have been societies without monogamy, with communal childcare, with matriarchal structures, etc, etc. Therefore, if said structure was biologically determined, then how would you explain these variations?

Name: Eveliina Hannele
wealth mindset
Comment:
@Abel Abel There is no cherry picking done because there is no ‚Äúoverarching narrative‚Äù to the red pill. Only information one chooses to discuss. 

Secondly how you ‚Äúfeel‚Äù about the information is only relevant when you intend to interpret the information emotionally. when the information (even raw data assuming the study isn‚Äôt biased) is interpreted logically and rationally, simple conclusions and best practices can be drawn. For example if you look at marriage statistics in America; 50% of marriages end in divorce, 80% of divorces are filed by women, 90% of alimony/child support is paid by men to women, and men lose child custody 90% of the time. Now, knowing this information any logical and rational person (particularly males since they suffer the most from divorce) can look at this data and logically conclude that marriage in America is not in his best interest. That‚Äôs just one example. Plenty of other examples out there.

Name: Abel Abel
Comment:
@wealth mindset Cherry-picked means that "information" contradicting the overarching narrative of "red pill" will be disregarded. You could simply look up the meaning of "cherry-picking".

How one "feels" about the "information" is quite important, especially on soft science fields (like psychology, sociology and economics), since one can easily jump to conclusions and to overarching narratives based own their on biases - whether they want it or not. Raw data means little without analyzing the shortcomings of experiments or, more importantly, the establishment of causation.

There is no information without one interpreting and writing it. Humans will always be involved, especially when studying, erm, humans.

Feel free to give more concrete examples. Discussing in general lines can be difficult.

Name: Kate W
Comment:
I hate the whole "If he pays, she needs to give up bodily autonomy" thing. I generally like to pay for myself whether with friends or on a date simply because I don't like feeling like a burden. But I happily pay for others from time to time when I can afford it because I want them to be able to participate and it's how I show I care. It never has to do with expecting something in return. And anyone who offers something and then expects something in return which was never agreed upon is gross.

People like that are difficult because they see the world as black and white with no grey areas. But relationships are individual. There's no steadfast rule for who should pay or how much sex to have or who should take out the trash because all partnerships are slightly different.

Name: Jamie Woodward

Lol racist much, his Australian and I do like his belief even if people don't understand how he explains himself. 

I was once very under weight and got alot of judgment over it, I won't go to deep into it but it made me workout and over eat to not be seen in that light. 

By about a year after I became over weight for my height. I thought I was only having anxiety but when I finally went to the doctors, they informed me that I was having angina attacks that were turning into mini heart attacks.

I was very lucky to get this information in time so I could change my eating habits.

After about another 12 months this had changed me for the best, I felt great and now am able to spend more time with my children without having a heart attack and dying on them.

It's a great message and just because I want to eat crappy foods shouldn't fall on the out come of my loved ones.

If me liking this message means I'm simping for Isaac, then I'm a simp lol

Name: Natalia Sanchez
Comment: @Markov Chain Hey that‚Äôs fantastic! üòäGood for you! Then now let me address something because I can see were I might come off as very optimistic in my post but Ima be real with you watching the state of discord in our country has made me extremely pessimistic honestly. Not only as a women who is seeing her rights to healthcare being challenged but also as a Puertorican seeing the supreme court punished someone who lived most of their life in America, for moving back to Puerto Rico. Its hard to read and its even harder to read people talking to each other on the internet because they literally are providing the material necessary to further alienate a whole group of people. The way people communicate is so unempathetic it hurts but thats why the divide only gets bigger. I‚Äôve said my fair share of things because I was letting emotions put my foot in my mouth BUT I‚Äôm also one to take steps back when I can tell I might have invalidated someone or if I didn‚Äôt have enough knowledge to continue. Like you I am also someone who like to read everything I can get my hands on so whenever I‚Äôm stuck I go read and learn more. Anyway let me address the point you said that everyone isn‚Äôt like me and yeah I know BUT again it doesn‚Äôt hurt to speak up and ask for clarification and if they still double down in a rude way then you just walk away cause why talk to someone not willing to apologize for invalidating you. You can set communication boundaries. I think all of us would benefit from being more open in dialogue. Also even if someone said it in a negative way ya might as well go damn thats some good advice if thats the only nice thing you have to say than I will be going now. Basically what I am trying to say in a long winded way is that we need more people to actively put themselves in other people‚Äôs shoes regardless of right or wrong. But as the state of discord in our Country has shown not many people are which fucking sucks üòÆ‚Äçüí®  Learning to communicate takes time but I am working on it everyday in hope that one day I can have more open conversations with people. Honestly I just want people to stop fearing what they don‚Äôt understand and to mind their business if it doesn‚Äôt affect them. As for your finally tid bit thanks for what you said I appreciate it as you can see I‚Äôm very passionate about these topics. Oh as for post graduation depression I literally got so sick after undergrad due to built up repressed PTSD symptoms that I was out of commission for 2 years and am now in grad school so haha I felt that too deeply. Anyways I‚Äôll just say hopefully some day more people will learn that dehumanizing someone just because they are in the wrong won‚Äôt get you anywhere because they don‚Äôt think they are and IT WILL LITERALLY GET YOU NOWHERE like omygosh is so hard to read and watch makes me want to beat my head against the wall üò© I‚Äôm honestly impressed by how bad people are at communicating

Name: Natalia Sanchez
Comment: Um you‚Äôll probably not read this since I am two weeks late to this comment but I am someone studying to be a psychologist and I literally say that to everyone when I see that they might need guidance to work through their issues. The fact that you think that me saying that is invalidating your feeling and calling you pathetic shows me your opinion on therapy. I think its a powerful thing to go to Therapy it takes a lot to actively work on yourself. Sometimes you alone is not enough and thats okay. I just want you to know that there are people out there who say statements like go to therapy because they genuinely want you to heal and work through what hurts you. I won‚Äôt lie to you that there are many communication barriers in society today and it sucks but I have some advice for you. If someone says this to you and you think they might be invalidating you, say that to them and ask them to clarify to you if that is not their intent. Therapy is an amazing resource especially when you find the right therapist for you (which might take time but who said working on yourself is easy). I just want you to know too that your feelings are valid and therefore you should be open to expressing them in order to understand the intent of a person. I get taught this a bunch in school about the importance of separating intent vs. Impact because you might not intend to cause harm when you say something but that doesn‚Äôt take away from the fact that the things you said hurt someone else. The other thing is meeting people as an adult and having time to put into them is really freaking hard, I don't know about you but I work 40+ hours a week and basically have no savings after rent, bills and groceries. I'm exhausted all the time and the way the world is right now makes me so uncomfortable I barely want to go out, especially where there's a lot of people. It's probably not that they're "not coopertating" but more of their time a seriously limited and their energy possibly nonexistent, so it's hard to build those relationships. You need to get a hobby and make friends. Friends will mean healthier more fulfilling relationships and it will open doors for potential romantic ones. But if you're going into every friendship with a woman with the end goal of sex or even a serious relationship, that will make it harder for you to really let your guard down and get to know her. Us women are always frightened by men because of our past experiences, we are hypervigilant and will notice if your motives are off. Just literally be yourself, treat her like you would one of the "boys" or any person you spend time with and things will go better. These things take time. If you want an overnight wife, try mail-order brides, because life doesn't work like that, unfortunately. My partner was on my periphery for a long time before we got together and it took a while for me to let my guard down but he was honestly the same, now we have one of the best relationships I could have imagined or have ever come across. And frankly, I was rejected by a lot of men before him. I had men threaten to rape me, call me fat and ugly for not immediately taking my clothes off for them, and treat me like shit for having opinions. Name: Jade Dunston
Comment:
Who should pay for a date? Whoever asked the other person out. 

Simple, gender-neutral, and fair. 

I would never ask a platonic friend, let alone a potential romantic partner, to join me for a movie or whatnot and then expect them to pay their own way. I wouldn't want to ask them to take on a financial burden just so that they could have the "privilege" of spending time with me. If I invite someone to dinner, I expect to pay the entire check. (I'm a cis woman, btw.) 

That said, I've been on dates with women who really put their foot down about going dutch, and I don't argue with that. I get it, because of the societal expectation that buying someone dinner entitles you to sex, some women are really uncomfortable with letting someone else buy their meal. (If a guy ever argued with me about paying the bill, I'd agree to go dutch with him as well...but, oddly enough, that rarely happens). But generally, if I'm the one who initiated the date, I come prepared to pay for both of us. And if someone asks me out and I don't feel comfortable with them buying me a meal or a movie ticket, I don't argue about who's paying for what. I just say no thanks.

Name: RatPfink66
Comment: @Ben Allmon Thank you for sharing all this.You have what looks to be a very healthy attitude based on staying together and growing together. I wish you the best.

Name: Ben Allmon
Comment:
@RatPfink66 Not sure but a good question for sure. My wife is a ride or die though. It might be the willingness to be better everyday and being vulnerable. I've been promoted and have helped her get promotions. We are both actively trying to grow in the same path and the same way. Constantly challenging each other to be better and to shed our toxic traits. It's something I've never found with anyone else. Not any friend or family member or previous girlfriend. 

Do I know this will last? I don't know but we are both committed to each other and trying hard to being open and honest with each other. We have had many fights and come out of them learning about ourselves and actively working on ourselves. 

Id say the one thing that kills most relationships is not being aware that you both grow as people. And without a focus on growing in the same direction, you will both become a massively different person than you were a year prior. We both want a family, both want to continue to climb in our jobs and both have the same end goals. When one of those change, we talk about it and compromise on what the best course of action is. I want to promote as much as possible while she wants to work until I can provide for the both of us, then take on a house keeper/tradition type wife role. That is her choice and I'm okay if she decides to change her mind and would be okay to be the stay at home Dad if needed. The ability to be flexible and have open communication has helped us so much. 

Tbh I just got lucky to have found her. She is a rare gem and all the years of being single and working on myself paid off in the best way possible. But even if we don't work out, it won't make me become like these red pilled weirdos. All women are not the same. Won't make me change on being vulnerable and open.

If you go in with unhealed wounds, it's only going to make matters worse. We take risks all the time. I don't stop taking my car just because I might get into a car crash, and god knows the chances are high. I don't stop being nice and kind just because my kindness was abused by others. We chatted a minute, and then he picked up a game out of the game library and said, "can you teach me to play this?" I said that I absolutely could, and as we sat down, he kind of announced that he had social anxiety, but that he was working on it. We've been together for eight and a half years. His complete openness and honesty impresses me to this day.

There are requirements placed on women in this scenario though. Heavy requirements. Matthew Hussey teaches women to stick to the "female" role and to pander to a man's ego. If you are going to insist on rigid "traditional" gender roles, then absolutely the man should pay. It's not reasonable to expect a woman to fulfil all the aspects of the "female" role and for the man to have few obligations to fulfil the "male" role.

If you want 50/50, then have egalitarian relationships and don't expect women to be submissive and feminine and put male desires first.

Edit: Yeah, aside from women growing up in a society where this thinking has been the norm, you can't criticise women for "not being taught right" and not doing things equally while also reinforcing old gender roles. You can't have it both ways, Matthew. He expects women to fulfil their gender role but to treat men as if they're in an egalitarian relationship. That is incredibly imbalanced. There are also far too many men who already think like this and it should not be encouraged. Either you both follow old gender role norms (which includes the man being a provider) or neither person follows them. Otherwise, it puts even more of a burden on women than women had in the past when strict gender roles were the norm - all the work and vulnerability without the benefits.

Also, Matthew is basically equating dating to prostitution here.

Matthew Hussey sells bad dating advice to desperate women, encouraging them to bend over backwards to please a man, threatening them with being alone if they don't follow these "rules" because "men won't want them". Like so many providing bad dating advice for women. It comes with a fake dusting of "female empowerment" and  "caring for and respecting women" but underneath this superficial marketing bs his advice is quite misogynistic and awful and rather conservative. He started off as a dating coach for men then found this was more lucrative. He's also a serial cheater and all-around douchebag. No one should be getting advice from him. Name: A mo
Comment:
@Jason original claim I replied to: "No, humans do not have mating strategies like other animals. We don't do *anything* like other animals in terms of finding a mate"

My reply: We are still animals at the end of the day. *Just very unique in some senses. In other senses, not so much.*

The full introduction: Relative to those of other animals, *human mating strategies are unique in their relationship with cultural variables such as the institution of marriage* .[1] Humans may seek out individuals with the intention of forming a long-term intimate relationship, marriage, casual relationship, or friendship. The human desire for companionship is one of the strongest human drives. It is an innate feature of human nature and may be related to the sex drive. The human mating process encompasses the social and cultural processes whereby one person may meet another to assess suitability, the courtship process and the process of forming an interpersonal relationship. *Commonalities, however, can be found between humans and nonhuman animals in mating behavior, as in the case of animal sexual behavior in general and assortative mating in particular.*

To prove them wrong, I just have to show them at least *1* instance of humans and other animals showing similarities.This tells me you ignored some information to suit your own agenda. The same thing you accused me of.

@John Williams It might shock you to discover this but most men don't base their beliefs on what will get women to date them/have sex with them. They have their own identities and views and values. The men (and women because there are women like this too) who base their beliefs, etc. on what appeals to people of the gender/s they're attracted to, who mould their views and identity on making themselves more desirable to people of the gender/s they're attracted to are desperate and needy people who have issues with people-pleasing. It is not healthy. It is also very off-putting to most people and so, ironically, makes it more likely that people who behave in this way will be rejected.

Almost everyone goes for looks, especially initially, regardless of gender. But for most people views and values are also very important. Because you're also looking for a companion and someone with incompatible views is less likely to be a good companion, and people with certain toxic views are almost certain to be bad companions.

Republican males and conservative males in general are not more attractive. They do not have better genetics and they do not have better lifestyle choices. They are more attractive to women who share their values, who like more "traditional" men, and who like a more conservative aesthetic. Other women are more attracted to different things and might find conservative men unattractive.

You seem to be confusing fantasy with reality.

Name: remote assistance
Comment: (straight woman for context) after i went through a bad break up, i had such a weird conception around the perfectly normal experience of rejection. i felt ..like a freak honestly bc the media reception is that it's "normal" for men to be rejected but "girls are gonna have sex with any guy they want to" which was not my experience. i found myself falling into that toxic thinking that guys will just go after women that are "traditionally attractive". i found myself resenting men and other women, so i took a long break for romantic relationships. i had to remind myself to look at people as people. men, women, romantic context, platonic context, whatever. it's not about "metrics". it's not formulaic. finding someone that likes you and that you enjoy as well is hard. it does seem like people have it super easy so it's easy to develop resentment. but i have had a lot more fulfilling relationships (romantic, casual, platonic) by focusing not on outside characteristics and concepts, but just having a "human experience" with other people.

Name: Ann Ward
Comment:
Capitalism is literally killing me on the fast track, dear Noah, I hear you. I‚Äôm sorry you have to move and produce when you do not want to. At the same time, this was an excellent video- there‚Äôs growth happening in this discussion. I see you applying things from Fiq‚Äôs Manosphere vids that I align with, and rly taking it to the core root of the problem. Patriarchy- which hurts everyone. It‚Äôs the same w racism & White Supremacy as well. No one is free until we are all free. It‚Äôs hard to find empathy for someone who doesn‚Äôt present as wanting to change or dismantle the patriarch that is the cause of the problem but pushes it as a solution, because they get all the privileges from it even tho ultimately, it‚Äôs gonna kill them too. But it‚Äôs the only way if I‚Äôm truly humanizing these men and wanting freedom from oppression for all. Which I do. 
But I‚Äôd be I liar if I said they were prioritized in my life in my personal deconstruction. 
I‚Äôm a white woman, I think this sentiment is often (rightly) felt about us. We‚Äôll take all the benefits of White Supremacy, and fight for things that only benefit us as women. No intersectionality. So I‚Äôm not surprised when in a room of mixed company, no one is interested in our opinions. 
What do we do, surround these men with unconditional love until they feel safe enough to break down and get to their core emotions? Just keep them surrounded w unconditional love w a safe space to be? Everyone deserves that, I think. Wouldn‚Äôt that be dope. 

Thank you Noah.

Name: hummusiguess
Comment:
@Tip Toes ¬†i'm autistic haha. There may be a pattern here lol.

 I think the neurodivergency may explain why I ended up doomscrolling do much when i was mentally ill. I could relate to the loneliness and self hatred of incels, but not their politics, Whereas i agreed with lefty politics but hated how condescending and careless they were. They seemed more than fine with making things worse as long as they felt superior in the end (eg. Making fun of incels for being virgins, ben shapiro for being short, and thus perpetuating patriarchal standards). 
 Like, I don't have much of an issue with people making fun of hate groups, i just wish they'd do it without being hypocrites. I hated browsing through either community and both made me feel more worthless.

I think a lot of this may be result of a sort of 'mutual invalidation' (idk im bad with words), where people invalidate each others experiences for moral superiority, leading the other side to feel angry and perpetuate the cycle. I think the black pill/pink pill thing is a good example with how each communtiy views each other -in the eyes of each community, the other doesnt deserve to exist because their problems are seemingly insignificant. 

God i fucking hate social media. The worst part is how these apps thrive off this toxicity, whether it be twitter, reddit, 4chan or tiktok, the more hateful and addicted people get, the more money theyll make.

I hope i didn't ramble too much lol; this is probably a lot more disjointed than my last comment.

@hummusiguess I don't disagree with you at all about all of what you said. I also think people are playing tennis games with a lot of political and social issues in general. The Internet has definitely made a lot of us more socially inapt to some dangerous levels for humanity. Creating more division by that. I hate that so many make humans interactions even more complicated. I'm neurodivergent, so it's very confusing to me why some people would do that. You are not pessimistic on this concept. Observing humans to try to understand them. (Must be my neurodivergence.) I don't know. Anyway, enough about me. lol

I didn't see your comments as condescending. But I'm happy to know that they were not, though. üôÇ 


I also have no solution. The ones that need help the most are too often the ones who won't get help, unfortunately. 
Being human is so complex...

Name: hummusiguess
Comment:
@Tip Toes yeah I can see how it could help people know who to avoid; but I do also get the feeling it does more harm than good. OP has been left feeling as if dating as a whole is just too risky (an idea which she obviously is allowed to believe and practice).

 I don't think this is really going to sort out the wider issues at play here, and I think what's happening to OP is something eerily similar to what's  happening to red pillers, where so many unhappy people are staying online and watching videos that make them hurt, while also damaging how they view other humans and social interaction as a whole. And i think one of the most insideous parts of this is how it can be masked as 'education', where you convince yourself you're just listening to people tell it like it is (take the similarities between red and pink pillers for example).

Maybe i'm pessimistic, but i don't think we currently have the kind of political tools (neither the understanding of what causes this, or the support structures to prevent it) to really adress these problems. 

Like, OP's comment isn't very popular, so why did you feel the need to scroll through all these comments? Do you really feel like you've learned valuable lessons you could've learned without making yourself so uncomfortable? The same goes for me too obviously, even though I'm a guy. I think we're all just collectively watching content that makes us feel bitter and miserable so we can excuse not making an effort to actually persue change irl (maybe idk just conjecture).

I don't mean to be condescending - not to you, nor OP, but I really don't think 'the left' really had any good solutions to some of these problems yet, which is concerning i guess.

Name: Thomas Foolery
Comment:
@Luci Evelyn  haha. Translation: ‚ÄúCrap. This guy is smarter than I thought he was. He really logically cornered me with that point about how our feminist mainstream movements never call out women like they do to men. I‚Äôll say I won‚Äôt be responding any further to save face before he completely dismantles my entire world view.‚Äù

You don‚Äôt have to respond anymore. I understand you need to save face. I‚Äôll respond to your last post for anyone else following this thread.

I have read very widely. I‚Äôm using a pseudonym for fun here, but I‚Äôve actually debated some of the top feminists that have best selling books that you probably parrot your talking points from.

One big misconception on your part is the idea that feminism moves in a line of progress over time and anyone who isn‚Äôt using your latest jargon is simply behind. Are you not aware that there are many conflicting ideas within the wider feminism movement? For example, is sex work empowering to women or is it exploitative? There are many prominent feminists who disagree here. The entire movement is a series of overlapping Venn diagrams. The one line of feminism you were indoctrinated by is likely the line your liberals arts classes all coalesced around. There is a ton of feminist literature that contradicts the points you seem to see as set in stone. I don‚Äôt owe it to you to magically figure out which line of feminism you were indoctrinated by. However, I happen to be familiar with all of them.

You missed the point about buzzfeed young one. Yes, I know all of you gen Z kids use tiktok now. Hilarious considering you don‚Äôt understand that the CCP owns that and it designs the algo to nudge your ideological views to where it wants it, but that‚Äôs a separate point. I used Buzzfeed to make a point about ‚Äúmainstream feminism‚Äù. Buzzfeed, NYT, etc represent what is accepted as the correct mainstream position. You can find anyone with any position on social media. Yet, they won‚Äôt be having their TikTok videos studied and reviewed as the class textbook in college. There is a wider ideological debate about what is the correct mainstream position, and that‚Äôs what shapes the minds of America not some dumb tiktok edge lords.

The mainstream feminist position is inherently hypocritical. That is my point. I don‚Äôt particularly care for whatever fringe part of feminism you happen to adhere to this week. It holds no power over society unless it gets folded into the mainstream position which is how laws are shaped and class curriculums are decided.

Your attempt to point out the difference in weight between using men for food and abortion laws was illogical. You could have just compared it to mansplaining to make it of equal weight. First of all, I never mentioned abortion, you did, in order to give weight to your comparison. Second of all, it isn‚Äôt the weight that matters it‚Äôs the logical consistency. When you come up with some abstract ideological explanation to justify bad female behavior for petty issues, you should do the same for men. That is my point.

Lastly, I‚Äôd like for you to grasp the concept that newly written feminist literature isn‚Äôt science. There are no proofs. There is no QED moment. It is literally nothing more than ideological opinions. Hilarious considering that‚Äôs exactly what manosphere content is. Guys like Rollo Tomassi have written a ton of books and it is the ‚Äúmasculinist‚Äù equivalent. It is all religious thinking on both sides. It‚Äôs their vision of how society should deal with the genders and why it makes the most sense. If you take away nothing from our exchange, please wrap your head around only this. If you can‚Äôt grasp this, you‚Äôll be recruited into a cult at some point in your life and go around parroting the words of the cult leader for the rest of your life making him rich.

Name: Luci Evelyn
Comment:
@Thomas Foolery This just indicates you haven't read very widely, and that you are either a) not understanding my points, b) not reading carefully or c) deliberately misconstruing them. Nowhere did I say "don't call out those things", although you must exist in quite the echo chamber if you haven't seen the thousands of tik toks and memes calling out that behaviour in women. 

But, if buzzfeed is your reference point then perhaps you aren't super "with the times". 

Your language choices of what to do with men saying misogynist stuff is also very telling. If you think it's "shaming" and "forcing them to conform" then I really don't think you have a particularly good understanding of the issues. You also are equating two things that are in no way equal. Women's reproductive freedom is being erroded because of the views around women at this very moment. Women using men for free food does not have this widespread implication. 

My points are relevant. You are the one lacking in knowledge of feminist theory if you think that definition is remotely current. Not even the older feminist theorists use such a simplistic view (e.g. De Beauvoir). 

Because of your continued lack of understanding of my point, and refusal to address any of what I say, I'm not going to bother to respond further. I see no value in continuing to talk to someone who is a) ignorant of the topic and b) arrogant and rude in asserting that ignorance and c) refuses to engage properly. It's intellectually lazy on your part, and quite frankly you aren't up to scratch on the definitions and concepts, not to mention potential damage of one activity vs. another. 

Do better. Read more. I sincerely hope you can do your research and read more widely, in order to come to a deeper and better understanding that isnt coloured by your own perceived victimhood. I'd love for providing free food to be the only risk to my gender.

Name: Thomas Foolery
Comment:
@Luci Evelyn you are redefining it. The definition of Patriarchy I used isn‚Äôt the first definition, it‚Äôs the ideological definition. Your definition has drifted from the ideological definition by feminists before you. Frankly, it doesn‚Äôt really add/remove from the discussion, but I point it out to say that it‚Äôs absurd for you to expect me to know which non-textbook feminist definition you‚Äôre using and blame that on me as if I didn‚Äôt do the appropriate research. It says a lot about your entitlement.

‚ÄúThese women are at fault, but that won‚Äôt change until you change the underlying system.‚Äù 

It isn‚Äôt that I don‚Äôt understand this. It‚Äôs that you‚Äôre wrong. When men have a patriarchal view of things such as ‚Äúwomen should raise the children‚Äù you call men backwards and sexist and shame them until they conform to your viewpoint. You don‚Äôt dodge the point then say,‚Äùmen feel this way because of the patriarchy. We need to dismantle that system or men won‚Äôt change.‚Äù Lol.

Men and women are equal right? So hold them accountable like you do to men. Write some buzzfeed article with the headline,‚ÄùLadies, your backwards expectation for men to pay for you is misandrist and reinforcing the patriarchy. Do better.‚Äù

No single raindrop thinks they‚Äôre responsible for the flood. Be the change you want to see in the world.

Name: Luci Evelyn
Comment:
@Thomas Foolery If you think the dictionary definition is the one being used by feminist theorists, with no expansion, you're the one ill informed. As I've said, look into more nuanced understandings, because that's what we're working off. 

Women using men for free food, partially part of patriarchal conditioning that men are supposed to pay for dates. That's what is meant by systemic problem. Those women are at fault. But that wont change until you address the underlying system of values and behaviours that allow for it. I''m not sure why you don't understand this? It's really not very complicated. 

And, I am on topic. I'm explaining why even the definition you listed doesn't just "mean men". And then explaining what people mean BEYOND the dictionary when they say "patriarchy". You listed a dictionary answer and failed to comprehend even the implications of that.

I'm sorry, but I think you're too caught up in your own agenda here to be able to have an actual conversation. And that's me being charitable to you and your capacity for reason and reading comprehension.

P.S. expansion on a definitions based on the academia from that field is not "redefining" it.

Name: Alyson Martin
Comment:
10:15 I applaud you for this video, Noah, because I think it‚Äôs a message these men need to hear. I‚Äôm also glad to see that spaces for feminist men have begun forming online. What I‚Äôm hearing is that there are no safe spaces for men to discuss the parts of the patriarchy that affect them negatively‚Ä¶and that‚Äôs why many of them find comfort within the manosphere. But men need to set these spaces up for themselves and each other, the same way non-men have. That‚Äôs not something the rest of us can, should, or will do for men.

Yeah, I can see women perpetuating shitty ideas around men and their emotions, and they shouldn‚Äôt do that, but still the quote you shared on this topic rubbed me the wrong way. It implies that women are a significant source of the derision that keeps men closeting their emotions, which it provides no measurable basis for‚Ä¶men made the patriarchal rules, benefit the most from patriarchal privilege, and yet women are being called out for not ‚Äúrewarding‚Äù men for getting in touch with their feelings? If you‚Äôve unpacked your shit and understand why emotions and gender equality are important, that should‚Äôve been the reward in and of itself. You shouldn‚Äôt be a feminist just to get positive female attention, you should do it because it‚Äôs morally correct and is better for everyone.

*At the end of the day, no one has more power to relieve themselves from the influence of the patriarchy than men.* And until ya‚Äôll start really talking to each other instead of continuing to point out how the rest of us are doing it wrong, we‚Äôre not getting anywhere.

Name: RatPfink66
Comment:
@Alyson Martin well, one thing we know as men is that _other men will not_ support us on that journey as a rule, and indeed, will often do what they can to invalidate it. 

we're not all in this together. if we succeed, we're a threat in a primal way.

Name: djangogeek
Comment:
@Alyson Martin Consider this: slavery could not have ended without hundreds of thousands of white people dying to end it. Does that mean that there were no black soldiers who fought in the war? Of course not. Even though it was white peoples responsibility to end slavery, black soldiers also fought proudly to end the institution, *and it couldn't have happened without them.*

Wouldn't it make sense then, that the war to end patriarchy will need women to proudly fight alongside men to end that* institution as well? Because much in the same way, *it can't happen without women.* To brush it off as "not my fight not my problem" is far too short sighted.

Name: Alyson Martin
Comment:
@Noah Samsen thank you for the clarification. I haven‚Äôt read that book - I‚Äôll put it on my reading list! And you‚Äôre welcome üíõ I love your videos and the discussions you start.

I still can‚Äôt help but be a bit plucked. Women have had to build upon the victories around our own liberation without the support or validation of men/society at large. The rhetoric that red pill men need our validation and understanding to do the right thing by them and us feels like asking too much. It‚Äôs hard to consolidate that feeling. Maybe hooks has a point that would help with that.

Name: Noah Samsen
Comment: I think "reward" is meant to refer to just like, validation, and understanding more than anything else (as opposed to derision or scorn as hooks points out). Reward in this sense shouldn't be a motivation, but without it, it really is difficult for those most affected to be able to grow. I definitely agree that the quote by itself implies significant blame on the part of women, but the rest of that chapter (and book) make it very clear that the harm will always ultimately fall on the side of the oppressed, which is women under patriarchy. It's a synthesis between those two notions (Men ultimately are the oppressors in a systemic manner + Men are hurt by this same system and ignoring that pain hurts us all in the long run). It's a good read if you haven't! Also, thanks for the nice comment!

Name: Jaistashu
Comment:
As a femme non-binary, it's my understanding that each person should go into the date expecting to pay for whatever they order for themselves. If I order a bottle of wine, then I pay for that bottle of wine, and I share said wine. If my date orders the appetizer, they pay for it. If I want any, I'll ask their permission before I eat some of the appetizer they ordered. I don't like the idea of "splitting" the check bc it implies evenly splitting the total when what each person ordered more likely than not ranges in price. If I ordered chicken tenders for 10 bucks and my date ordered steak for 22 bucks, I don't think it's fair for me to pay 16 bucks and vice versa.

Ultimately, I hate the idea that a man or masc person is expected to pay for everything not only bc it's the gateway thought into "I bought you things so now you owe me sex", but also bc men have bills, too. I don't want my spending time with my date to hang on whether or not I've burned through too much of their money. I don't want to associate spending a nice time together with exponential money loss.

Comment: I'm 50 now and so far out of the dating pool I can't smell the chlorine, but this is how I always wanted to date. At least at first. Can't we just hang out? Name: 75th
Comment:
@Keylanos Lokj Not really. Zoosk pulled data from over 40 million users and at all ages, even in their 50's, men typically only matched with women around their own age anyway. Their entire life, the woman was consistently only like 1-5 years younger. And that's consistent with all other stats we have showing the average age gap of couples being 1-4 years, even in older age. Slightly higher gap the older you are. Only 10% of relationships have an age gap of ten years and it shrinks the farther apart the couple is in age. So doesn't seem age has much to do with marriage or dating and their pool wouldn't really grow at all because they turned 30. It shrinks, for everyone since the best matches already paired up. 

Especially since men at 40 only have about a 5% chance of getting with a 20 year old, so they can't really go much younger anyway because women by far prefer men around their own age, or slightly younger when they get older. So for men who refuse to date their own age and only chase younger women they are almost guaranteed to erase themselves from the gene pool. There are more young women than young men, and women only start to dominate in terms of numbers once men start dying off at around 60-65 years old. So before then, there really aren't enough women to go around because more men are born. 

Doesn't add up either way. After 60, sure. Senior men definitely have a slightly larger pool because there are more women than men. But before then not at all. Maybe it's because young women are more naive in what they want. Then they get older and are more picky because they refuse to waste their time on assholes. Maybe men just get who they can, then. That's the only way I can see that working out, is if men lower their standards whether in age or looks. 

Which means women would be the gate keepers of marriage at that point, because they refuse to lower their standards and are happier to remain single with friends than with the wrong man.

Of course I think what really complicates all of this, we're in the middle of financial and cultural shifts. Men are generally still expected to ask a woman out and take the risk of rejection. Women are working more now and in a growing number of cases, earning more than their prospective partners and often it's still frowned upon to date a man that makes less. All summed up, men and women are still rooted in some traditional aspects while we've been propelled well ahead in some areas. Change while for the better can be an ugly transformative process. Of course there are plenty of bitter men in the manosphere that reject some changes of equality.

Name: EJ
Comment:
@ApotheosiZ Ah okay, I see where there‚Äôs been some miscommunication. The term ‚Äòpatriarchy‚Äô doesn‚Äôt refer to simply older men in positions of power (though the imbalance of men to women in higher paid positions is another example).

It refers to the prevalent social attitudes, laws, values and norms that exist that largely work in favour of men in general.

It is a nebulous concept cos it‚Äôs not something you can physically see, but rather something that has cultural and societal effects. Kinda like racism. It‚Äôs not an item or a something you can touch, but we can absolutely notice the negative effects.

When people use the term patriarchy, it‚Äôs certainly not a catch all term to excuse away poor behaviour. Everyone is responsible for their actions. It‚Äôs more a tool to help explain how people‚Äôs behaviours can be influenced, consciously or unconsciously, by the world around them. 

Neither women nor men are expressly saying, ‚Äòyou must act this way or else‚Äô. No one expects special treatment, just to be respected, treated as an equal, and allowed to feel safe around others. 

What problems do you think would become worse? Honestly asking

Name: ApotheosiZ
Comment:
@EJ yeah but all of this is nuance... What is a guy suppose to do when women reinforce the same sentiments of "men needing to be masculine & dominant" while preaching equality & feminism yet expecting chivalry & special treatment?

What does that have to do with patriarchal hierarchies aka older men in positions of power? Especially if most women (& men) claim to despise them... I don't really think that the 20 to 25 year old women I saw at the club on Saturday playing games with guys and flirting with other men in front of their boyfriends (probably a few of them cheated on their current partners that night) happens because of a patriarchal society, if anything that sounds more like Darwinism & survival of the fittest.

I don't really like or agree with how a woman's (or a man's) poor behaviour, mindset, and actions can just be placed on something else like the patriarchy or some other ideological structure, I feel like it delineates and takes away from finding a proper conclusion to the problem.

The patriarchy is already collapsing but a lot of these problems continue to morph & mutate into something different, that (from my perspective) seems considerably worse.

Name: EJ
Comment:
@ApotheosiZ sure, so it‚Äôs not so much that it *causes* anyone to abuse anyone else. It‚Äôs more that attitudes like that cause abuse against men not to be taken seriously or actively laughed off. Largely because patriarchal attitudes reinforce the idea the men have to be strong, masculine or dominant always.

Using that lens, if a man isn‚Äôt seen as being those stereotypical ideals of what a man ‚Äòshould‚Äô be, then it lays the groundwork for cases of abuse where a woman is the perpetrator to be dismissed

Name: Emu
Comment:
@Clueless Drifter Not trying to come at you at all cus you seem genuine in wanting to have civil conversation, so I hope my comment comes off the same way :) Also I apologize if you already discussed this later in the thread, I really can't keep reading further down.
I do want to put it out there, that the exact same argument can be said of men. Ie: "Ask a random man on the street what they find attractive and you'll hear the same stuff. Skinny, big boobs, big ass, blonde(maybe redhead), 'child-bearing hips' and small waist." The thing is, I know that statement is not at all true for every man, it's just the loudest dudes proudly proclaiming their preferences, and often only hurts women who can't meet that standard.
The exact same thing happens with women. To say all women like jawlines and muscles, tall, what have you, is just false, and a wide generalization. Like with men, this generalization exists because the loudest women proudly proclaim their preferences, and by doing so, only hurt men who cannot reach them. (Also as a side note, I am a woman and actually do not find any of those physical traits attractive. I much prefer shorter men, and preferably without a jaw that will cut me lmaoo. Lean is a big no for me too).
I think it's harmful to take what we have seen and heard from a small group of loud people and use it as evidence of one side being "less individualistic", especially because the individualality discussion is much too close in theory to the intellect discussion (Of course you were not linking the two, but often they are hand in hand). I know when I was younger I used to think all men were "single-minded, with their only goal being sex" and yeah, there are men out there like that, but it is harmful to act on it as if fact and not just my perspective. Especially since that idea is false, and I feel the same way with your generalization. It is all too easy to find evidence of women seemingly being single-minded and liking the same things, but it's only a small portion of women. To portray it as all women is harmful.
Not to mention, both women and men's  personal preferences on the other gender have been sorta taught generation to generation. We were taught that skinnier was more attractive and that bigger(not obese) was sickly and unhealthy. Similar beauty standards have been born from the patriarchy for decades if not centuries. These beauty standards effect both men and women of course, but is the reason the loud people in each group feel so comfortable announcing it and even applying it to others.
I mean, take one look at modelling agencies and see what they are searching for in models. Modelling agencies make money off models that are appealing to a general audience. And since more often than not, these agencies are heavily driven by money, you will see more often the models they hire are the ones most likely physically attractive to the largest audience.
There was something else I'd wanted to say, but it has slipped my mind and I think this comment is already too long haha.

Name: Allison Hart
Comment:
‚Äã@Markov Chain I apologize for leading with a derisive tone right out of the gate. It's just that, I've debated a lot of people who self-identify as MGTOW/MRA/etc. and most of them view women as subhuman NPCs, or at least inferior to them in some way. They will claim that that's not what MGTOW is about, but then say "all women are the same." So, I'm already on the defensive in that sense, and, sorry for that.

(Also ATLA is awesome) 

But, you did start out with what I see as an assumption that women are liars if they give that answer to the question, and I feel it would be difficult for you to prove that claim. I mean, there's the whole "Clearly women don't care about a man being smart, funny, having hobbies, etc. because they won't date a man under 6 feet," but this is exactly the argument I have a problem with. Sure, some women won't date a man under 6 feet tall, but some will. To say "women do X or don't do Y" seems like an essentialist argument to me and, I get that the point being made is that even if there are a few exceptions it doesn't change the "rule" about women. But regardless, it is coming from a stance that most/all women are fundamentally a certain way. Fundamentally "hypergamous," for example. 

"But most guys today (in the west or Murica at least.) are single and celibate."

I feel like there are too many factors as to why this is, to boil it down to women only caring about looks. I think it's more like, dating apps and technology are destructive and alienating, but not in the way TRP means; it's more like, romance being boiled down to a photo, a sentence, and an algorithm is a recipe for people becoming isolated, cut off from reality, and disillusioned. Rather than a problem of "the women on the dating apps," it's the dating apps themselves, and our hedonistic, quick-entertainment society, that don't promote genuine connections between people anymore.

About your last argument ‚Äì isn't part of the belief system of the red-pilled man that all women share the "same nature"? Manipulative etc.? So I'm confused by the argument that they don't fall for nice women. Since as far as they believe, nice women don't exist, right?

Name: Digaddog
Comment:
@Corduroy's Cloverleaf I don't understand your logic.  Gender stereotypes tend to mirror each other, right?  If we associate trait with gender, then we must associate other trait with other gender, or else there is no difference.  While I don't deny that women are stereotyped as weak, men are stereotyped as dangerous.  You choose to focus on the former stereotype, even when the latter stereotype is most relevant, as in court cases.  

There are a couple reasons this matters, mostly implicit reasons.  First off, it portrays the women's stereotype as the one in need of change.  I have to wonder, is it really better to charge women more time or men less?  In some cases, maybe, but in general, men being treated as dangerous is much more important, especially where intersectionality applies. 

Second, oftentimes this is just an extension of more sexism.  Theres this thing called gamma bias and an extension of it called ASCHITI model.  These go over how we attempt to minimize mens issues and portray women as agency-less.  We perpetuate these problems when we choose to portray mens issues as misogyny. 

Third, this drives the men we're trying to help away.  They see their issues minimized and they look for people who don't minimize their issues.  When they come across people like us, they're receptive at first, but the moment we frame their issues as something against women, they believe that we're the same as everyone else who minimizes their issues.  I recall a couple days ago, there was an article that said feminists found the draft sexist because it said women were weak, and someone replied something like, "for a second there I was worried we cared about men."  Theres this idea in MRA circles that feminists believe that equality will trickle down.

Fourth, I worry people care about performative progressivism more than actual progressive ideology.  I've seen people get away with tradcon beliefs in progressive spaces just because they scapegoated the patriarchy for their problems. 

Fifth, what about the cases in which sexism can not directly be attributed to patriarchy?  The instances in which an attempt at progressive policy, or women using soft or hard power to cause a change, can instead be shown to cause sexism?  I mean, this thread basically started by a progressive treating women as a monolith, even though some of the examples shown in this video (for example, paying for the first date) are shown from the perspective of a woman.  Examples of these can be found in actual policy as well.  This causes the same type of people who we discussed in point three to think, "some of these people do care, but what's the point if they can't pinpoint the causes?"

I wont say we can't analyze these issues through these lenses, just keep some things in mind. 

1.  Dont use this as a tool to minimize issues men face or their other causes.  Dont use it as a whataboutism.  

2.  Women aren't a monolith, and they're not always that progressive.  Every time I see a male survivor post about about their experience, someone without fail brings up how either women are more accepting than men.  Whenever I see a man talk about how he was treated afterwards, they contradict this.  The data we have also shows this.  I see similar problems with makeup/gender expression.  This isn't to say that all women are like this, just that we shouldn't automatically assume one way or the other.  

3.  Keep in mind the times that progressivism, as opposed to patriarchy, caused problems for men, even if they're rare.  I see people support the Duluth model to this day, for example.  Leftists tend to fight long lasting systematic issues, so I feel they tend to see the world as more static than it actually is.

The video kept point 1 and 2 in mind, so I don't have as much of a problem with it.

Name: Ian
Comment:
Restaurants were historically often segregated for lunch service, with women allowed only in groups of other women and/or restricted to private dining areas. More respectable/upper-class restaurants would refuse entry to single women in the evenings driven by the fear/moral panic that they might be sex workers soliciting clients. That said it was not uncommon to have back door accommodations attached to the same establishments for single men and women to intermingle out of view from polite society.

The reason men traditionally pay is because women did not traditionally work and when you're an old-timey man courting an old-timey young woman, you are the only only one who CAN pay. Paying for the meal is part of showing your feathers; it's proving that you can support/provide or whatever. This persists into the modern day because people are weird.

Name: cilla
Comment:
I'm not a man, but I am non binary and always looking for better, healthier examples of what it means to be "a man". "Define what a man is" should be the next trending line tbh. The last third of F.D. Signifier's latest Manosphere video, and a lot of what you get to in this video, I believe is signaling that this is a conversation more people are ready to actually get into: who is going to make a "safe space" for men like this? A space for them to comfortably explore and redefine their masculinity, to question the angry projections they've had shoveled on them for decades, to find a supportive community headed by welcoming, understanding, compassionate, well-studied people who themselves embody a healthier picture of masculinity and manhood. The next wave of content creators really needs to be that. It will save lives, it will put other people out of harm's way, it can reverse a culture of anger and control and blame.... they need to be saved with agitprop just as neonazis got redirected by a wave of dedicated (if fallible) political streamers.

Anyway, if you haven't seen that F.D. Signifier video, it's a good one to follow this one up with

Name: Pattern Recon
Comment:
A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). The plural women is sometimes used in certain phrases such as "women's rights" to denote female humans regardless of age. Denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs, distinguished biologically by the production of gametes (ova) which can be fertilized by male gametes.

A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.
Prior to adulthood, a male human is referred to as a¬†boy¬†(a male¬†child¬†or¬†adolescent). 
Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. During puberty, hormones which stimulate androgen production result in the development of¬†secondary sexual characteristics, thus exhibiting greater differences between the sexes. These include greater muscle mass, the growth of facial hair and a lower body fat composition.

Name: Minty Hippo
Comment:
Not that making content on the subject/providing examples of support are not important, but I feel like the most important thing is to encourage socialization.
With phones and media constantly putting the most extreme messages in your face constantly, it is easy to get sucked in and think the world is horrible. When I was growing up, I had a very negative view of women because of the media I watched. As I grew up, learned the value of getting to know people, and talked through my thoughts, I realized that I was way off. People don‚Äôt really view women negatively day to day. Jokes and jerks aside. Like, of course improvements can be made, but it‚Äôs not as bad as it is made out on the internet. (Not everyone is out to get women, etc) 

Videos/articles/movies only show a fraction of one person‚Äôs idea of something presented in a way to get more people to engage. Typically negatively.

Name: Zen Raloc
Comment:
@Christian Wallace I see, well you're not wrong with that last statement. Pity Parties never Prosper XD. And I can agree with some of that. Especially regarding generalization. But the OPs point was to suggest that it happens to women too, because people think it doesn't happen to woman and only happens to men. Which is just not true. It happens to both at varying degrees depending on what, when, and where.
Personally I see the issues more so in the manner of people to people. I don't feel like using the patriarchy theory (I say loosely because I believe we have moved past that already) arguement is not constructive because it eludes to the full responsibilities all parties have towards how they act as humans. I don't think it's fair to merely suggest people are under influence still from gender roles. That's too easy. I feel as though it also stems from everyone's ability to evade concern for others feelings. People are less so in control of their own emotions and less capable of hearing out others and communicating than they should be. And to be honest I think that happens to do with other factors like, ego, self importance, impatience. People are influenced and told to adhere to confidence but they oversell it and end up being too boxed in and defective. People are overly naturally defensive even when it's an outward conversation about another person opinion, (they attack), and alot of our current technology habitually lowers are patience for proper and full communication. It's a serious issue.
I dont disagree with their still being some individuals influenced by the patriarch though. They should've moved past gender roles and thinking that females are lesser beings quite some time ago.
Some people are even contrarian. Such as extreme feminists and meninists who don't understand actual gender equality.

Name: Zen Raloc
Comment:
@briansupermega I definitely can recognize they are treated more favorably in certain manners. Such as emotional expression. But not all manners. And in many ways they are still treated poorly. And this is still by the same people who want men to be able to be heard more aswell. Alot of people push the notion of equality but don't actually believe in real equality such as extremist meninists/feminists
I wasn't disputing that woman in this case get more favouritism. And if i was it wouldnt make me brainwashed. It'd just be a different experience and perception in life than yours. Don't be so close minded. I wonder if you even read what I said. The other guy mentioned that men Don't get to express themself AT ALL, that's not true. Relationships and expression  are also alot more common and balanced than people realize nowadays. There are plenty of woman who will hear out man express themself. Out of the 30ish woman I've dated in my life so far I can only think of one that didn't validate my opinion or emotional expression. And I'm very exceptional at communicating.

Which brings up another issue by the way. Alot of the times people want to be heard but not hear others. Why should a man/woman have to listen to their partner if their partner never listens to them.
Most men I know that think they are emotionally validated, care less about the opinion of their partner than theirs and don't communicate well.
The biggest reason this exists is because of a personal non gender specific trait that someone has. It's not a patriarchal thing (which by the way, was developed by men). Stop pretending the patriarch still had influence over us. Telling other people that narrows your perception and perpetuates the ideology and control of it. That's a cop out for people who don't see the true issue. It's in people. People don't see equality with others. They see no reason to be compassionate or perceptive of others feelings and opinions. You can't truly find middle ground or understanding of others without proper communication. That's what people lack nowadays. It's not a societal brainwashing XD
